proposals.reasoning: This fits the ‘boring baseline but spread info’ idea people have been circling: Alice is the common anchor most are comfortable with, Eve has been in a lot of suggested variants without much pushback, and Henry gives us an additional data point without auto-pairing Alice and Bob again. It keeps the team low-drama while not clustering only the default-safe trio together, which should give us a useful early read.

votes.comment: Early quest, I’m on the team, and it matches the low-drama/info-spread consensus; we need data and nothing here looks uniquely suspicious yet.
I’d rather avoid putting Henry on the very first team so we don’t lock in too many assumptions off a single early result.
Contains one known evil (Henry), giving our side options while fitting the table’s low-drama preferences.
Reasonable low-drama Quest 1 team that spreads info without obvious red flags; fine as an initial baseline.
Reasonable low-drama spread for Q1 that avoids auto-pairing Alice/Bob and gives good early info on Henry and myself.
Solid low-drama spread for Q1 that avoids auto-pairing Alice/Bob and gives useful early info on Eve and Henry.
Early mission with one evil on it gives us flexibility—either a safe pass for cover or a controlled fail for info, and the composition looks reasonable enough not to draw suspicion on me.
I’m fine with a low-drama opener that includes me; early mission info, even with a possible fail, is useful for shaping narratives.
Close to the kind of spread I wanted (Alice anchor plus Eve/Henry info) and nothing strongly pings evil yet; good enough for an informative Quest 1.

discussion.content: For Quest 1 I don’t think we should over-engineer it—let’s start with a fairly “boring” team of people who aren’t all trying to drive the table narrative, so we get a clean baseline read without handing too much cover to anyone who’s being loudly persuasive.
I’m fine with keeping it simple here—something like Alice plus two relatively low-key voices (I’d volunteer myself and maybe Eve or Iris) feels like a reasonable starting baseline for Quest 1.
I like the “boring baseline” idea—Alice/Bob/Iris feels like a solid, low-drama first team so we get some info without overcomplicating Quest 1.

I’m okay with a low-drama first team, but I don’t love locking in three people who are already kind of “default safe” by table presence—maybe swap one of Alice/Bob/Iris for someone like Eve or Henry so we start spreading the information a bit wider.

I’m okay with the “boring baseline” approach, but I’d rather not cluster all the default-trust picks together—something like Alice / Bob / Eve or Alice / Henry / Iris feels better to me for spreading early info.
I like the idea of a “baseline” team that isn’t too flashy—Alice/Bob/Eve or Alice/Bob/Iris both work for me, with a slight preference for including Bob here so we get an early read on him.

I like the idea of a “baseline” too, but I’d slightly prefer mixing in someone who hasn’t been on a lot of proposed teams yet—Alice / Bob / Henry or Alice / Eve / Henry both feel like reasonable spreads of info to me.

I like the idea of a low-drama first team, but I’d slightly rather avoid auto-locking Alice/Bob together again—something like Alice / Eve / Henry feels like a good mix of “generally trusted” plus one newer data point.

I like keeping Alice on but I’d rather not auto-pair her with Bob yet—something like Alice / Eve / Iris or Alice / Henry / Iris feels like a good balance of “generally safe” plus spreading the early info a bit.

proposals.reasoning: The table has broadly converged on an Alice–Bob–Iris core as a solid starting point for Mission 2, since they’re all fresh picks relative to the failed Mission 1 team (apart from Alice) and are widely townread. Given the single fail on Mission 1 and the desire to avoid immediately recycling from that failed team, I’m leaving both Eve and myself off for now so we can get a cleaner information set. For the fourth slot, several people have expressed a slight preference for adding Charlie (or Diana) as a fresh test; choosing Charlie fits that consensus, keeps all but Alice off the previous failing team, and should give us a high-confidence read on a largely new composition while still reflecting the group’s stated preferences.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so the Mission 1 fail points to Eve or Henry; this team avoids both and uses mostly fresh players, giving a strong chance to succeed and good info.
Keeps both players from the failed team (Eve/Henry) off while testing a mostly fresh group that the table broadly trusts, giving us a good chance at a clean result and useful info.
I like that it avoids recycling from the failed Mission 1 team (except Alice) and brings in mostly fresh players for a clearer read.
Solid info-gathering team: splits the Mission 1 trio, keeps only Alice from the failed team, and adds three fresh, generally trusted players.
Mission 1’s fail points to exactly one of Alice/Henry (from my POV), and this keeps Henry off while testing Alice with three fresh players. Good chance of a clean mission and strong information gain.

Merlin is likely Bob or Grace and both supported an Alice–Bob–Iris core; if Alice were the spy from Mission 1 they’d avoid locking her in, so this fresh team with only Alice recycled looks good and informative.
Only one known evil teammate (Charlie) is on the team, giving us controlled sabotage potential and strong table consensus to pass it through.
Matches the Alice–Bob–Iris core I supported with Charlie as the fresh fourth; also keeps both me and Eve off the failed Mission 1 team for a cleaner read.
Strong consensus on Alice–Bob–Iris, avoids recycling Eve/Henry from the failed team, and only one overlap with the known-failed mission makes this a solid, informative early test.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 had a fail and I know I’m good, I don’t want both Eve and Henry together on the next team—at most one of them, and I’d really like to see fresh blood like Bob or Iris included instead.

I like the idea of breaking up Eve and Henry for this next team and bringing in some new faces like Bob or Iris, since we only had a single fail and don’t have to double down on that exact trio yet. Maybe start from Alice + two fresh picks and then choose just one of Eve/Henry if we really feel we need them.

I’m fine locking in Alice plus two fresh people like Bob and Iris, then choosing just one of Eve/Henry—right now I slightly lean toward keeping Henry over Eve unless Eve can really sell why she should be back on.
I like the idea of a core of Alice–Bob–Iris, and for the fourth I’d rather leave Eve off for now and see how Henry looks on a mixed, mostly new team.

I get why people want to split me and Henry after the fail, but from my POV that just means either he or Alice is the problem, so I’d rather see something like Alice–Bob–Iris plus one of Charlie/Diana than auto-lock Henry back in.
I’m good with the Alice–Bob–Iris core; for the fourth I’d slightly rather test Henry or Charlie than put Eve straight back on after a fail.
I’m on board with the Alice–Bob–Iris core, and I’d slightly prefer adding Henry so we can retest him in a mostly new group rather than sidelining him and learning nothing from that first fail.
I’m good with locking in Alice–Bob–Iris, but I’d actually rather see the fourth slot go to Charlie or Diana so we’re not immediately recycling from a failed team and can get a cleaner read.

I like the Alice–Bob–Iris core, and for the fourth I’d much rather bring in Charlie or Diana than recycle Henry/Eve from a failed team this early. Keeping all four slots “fresh” from that first mission should give us a much cleaner signal.

proposals.reasoning:
We’re down 0–2, so success matters more than pure info, but we still want a team that gives us some clarity. This group keeps overlap with the failing missions low while avoiding the players in the heaviest suspicion pocket.

- Alice was on both failed missions, so keeping her off is a priority.
- Eve and Henry were each on the first fail, so I’d prefer to leave that entire Mission 1 group off for now.
- Mission 2’s fail came from among Alice/Bob/Charlie (I know I’m good), and of those, Bob has generally been pushing for low-overlap/info-rich teams in a way that feels more consistent with good play. I’m comfortable taking exactly one person from that mission, and I choose Bob over Charlie.
- The table was very quickly converging on a Frank/Grace/Diana + Iris core. That near-unanimous rush makes me nervous about a possible coordinated evil pair in Grace plus one of Frank/Diana, so I’m intentionally excluding Grace to avoid handing an easy setup to a possible evil duo.
- Frank and Diana are still solid inclusions as fresh picks who weren’t on either fail, and they’re widely trusted; if this team passes, they both look very good going forward.

This lineup balances winning chances with structural info: if it succeeds, we likely clear Frank and Diana strongly and give Bob a good bump; if it fails, we’ve isolated the blame to a smaller, better-defined subset without re-using the most suspicious players from earlier missions.

votes.comment: I know at least one of Bob/Charlie/Iris is evil from Mission 2, and this team includes both Bob and Iris plus two untested players, which feels too risky at 0–2.
Grace and Henry are off, and Diana/Frank are structurally very likely good; at worst this team has one suspect slot, which is strong at 0–2.

I still prefer a Frank/Grace/Diana core plus exactly one from the prior fail; this skips Grace entirely and brings Bob back in over Charlie without enough justification, so it doesn’t feel like our best mix of success + info at 0–2.
Too much overlap with Mission 2’s fail (both Bob and Iris); I’d rather stick with the lower-overlap Frank/Grace/Diana core plus just one from the previous failing team for a cleaner, safer test.
This has both Bob and Iris from the failed Mission 2 instead of the safer Frank/Grace/Diana+Iris structure; doubling up overlap with a known fail feels too risky and gives murkier info.
Fits my earlier preference of a Frank/Diana/Iris base plus exactly one of Bob/Grace, keeps Mission 1 entirely off, and is a reasonable low-overlap shot at our first success.

Too many fresh picks with no confirmed evil overlap; if this passes and succeeds we learn little, and if it fails we still won’t know whether Bob (from the last fail) or a new player is to blame. I’d rather see a team that includes exactly one of Grace/Diana/Frank core plus clearer testing of Mission 2 suspects.

Keeps Bob from the last failing mission while dropping Grace from the widely favored core; I’d rather stick to the low-overlap Frank/Grace/Diana+Iris structure we were coalescing around for both success odds and cleaner info.

I know I’m good, and this keeps Alice/Eve/Henry off while using exactly one from the Alice/Bob/Charlie suspect pool. Frank and Diana are fresh and widely town-leaned; if this fails, suspicion focuses cleanly on Bob vs one of them, and if it passes we get strong clears. Given we’re down 0–2, this is a reasonable balance of win chance and info.

proposals.reasoning: This team completely avoids Mission 1 (Alice, Eve, Henry), where we know there was at least one spy, and uses only two players from Mission 2 (Bob, Iris), giving us a cleaner read than reusing a large overlap. The near-unanimous push for the Frank/Grace/Diana + Iris core looks coordinated and risks handing control to a possible evil pair, so I’m deliberately excluding Grace to avoid locking in that bloc. If this team succeeds, it strongly clears Bob and Iris from the Mission 2 fail; if it fails, we immediately know at least one of Bob/Diana/Frank/Iris is evil, without entangling the earlier highly-suspect group.

votes.comment: I know I’m good and Mission 2 had a fail, so at least one of Bob/Charlie/Iris is evil; this team has both Bob and Iris, so it’s guaranteed to include at least one spy.
Avoids known evil (Grace, Henry) and includes at most one of the Charlie/Iris suspect pair from Mission 2, while keeping overlap with both failed missions relatively low.
Still not a fan of double-stacking Bob and Iris from the failed Mission 2 and leaving Grace off; I’d rather see the Frank/Grace/Diana core plus just one of the prior-mission players for cleaner info.
I still prefer the Frank/Grace/me core with only one person from Mission 2; double-stacking Bob and Iris from a failed team feels too risky at 0-2.

Avoids the highly-suspect Mission 1 group and the Grace-centered bloc that a lot of players are pushing; this feels like a better test of the Mission 2 suspects without handing control to a potentially coordinated pair.
Minimizes overlap with both failed missions and aligns with Bob’s more measured suggestions over Grace’s hard push for the alternative core, which I trust slightly more right now.
This keeps all three known-suspect early players off the team at once and feels more like a dodge than a genuinely informative test lineup.

I still prefer the Frank/Grace/Diana+Iris team; this one double-stacks Bob and Iris from the last fail and pointedly drops Grace, which feels less informative and more like dodging the earlier consensus.

At 0–2 we can’t afford a high-risk info team; this lineup still includes Bob from the failed Mission 2 plus two players (Diana/Frank) who are part of the heavily pushed core, so there’s a real chance of multiple evils here and not enough table consensus to justify it.

proposals.reasoning: We still want to keep overlap with both failed missions relatively low while not automatically locking in the Frank/Grace/Diana core that’s been pushed. This team has only one member from Mission 1 (Eve) and one from Mission 2 (me, Bob), which keeps the information reasonably clean without double‑stacking Alice, who’s been on both fails. I’m deliberately leaving Grace and Henry off since Mission 1’s fail came under Grace’s leadership with Henry on the team, and I’d rather not treat either of them as part of a default core yet. Between the remaining options, Diana and Frank have been widely considered reasonable, and adding Eve gives us a solid, mixed group without leaning too hard into the near-unanimous Grace/Frank/Diana block that could be a comfortable home for an evil pair.

votes.comment: This team pulls one from each failed mission (Bob from M2, Eve from M1) without giving us the low-overlap, high-info structure we’ve been aiming for; I’d rather see a Frank/Diana core with a single, more carefully chosen overlap from earlier fails.

At 0–2 we can’t afford a risky mix, and this pulls heavily from the same cluster that’s been mutually reinforcing each other, which feels like we’re likely seating at least one of the remaining unknown evils.

This stacks both Bob and Eve from the failed missions while leaving Grace off after we just spent the whole discussion converging on a Frank/Grace/Diana core plus one from Mission 2; I’d rather stick closer to that low-overlap, higher-info structure.

Still has two players from the two failed teams (Bob from M2, Eve from M1); I’d rather hold out for the widely discussed Frank/Grace/Diana + Iris type of low-overlap team instead of this alternative that keeps both Bob and Eve in the mix.

Keeps us away from the heavily pushed Grace/Diana/Frank core plus Iris that could hide a coordinated evil pair. Given I know I’m good and Alice has been on both fails, this lineup (Bob/Diana/Frank plus me) looks more likely to be mostly good than the alternative cores being pushed.
Keeps overlap with each failed mission low, avoids the heavily pushed Grace/Diana core that could hide an evil pair, and includes Bob, who is a Merlin/Morgana candidate I’m comfortable testing here.

I still prefer the low-overlap Frank/Grace/Diana core plus a single Mission 2 member; this keeps Grace off entirely while re-adding Eve from the first fail, which doesn’t feel like our cleanest info team.
No evil on this lineup means a likely clean success for good; I’d rather see a team including at least one of Grace/Charlie/Henry first.

We’re at 0–2, so safety matters more than clever info. This team still double-dips from the two failed missions (Bob from M2, Eve from M1) while keeping the Frank/Diana core that’s been treated as auto‑good all round. I don’t want to risk a must‑pass mission on a setup that both reuses two prior-fail slots and leaves that core essentially untested.

proposals.reasoning: Most of the table has coalesced around a Frank/Grace/Diana core as a low-overlap way to move off the two failed teams, so I’m keeping that spine and adding exactly one player from Mission 2 for information. Including me (Charlie) gives us only a single overlap with the last fail instead of re-stacking both Bob and Iris, while still avoiding Alice who was on both failed missions and Henry who led the first fail. This lineup respects the earlier consensus for a Frank/Grace/Diana base, responds to Iris’s concern about us auto-locking one specific 4, and maximizes the informational value of the result by lightly touching Mission 2 without recreating its structure.

votes.comment: Best low-overlap option we’re likely to see before auto-approve: only one player (Charlie) from the Mission 2 fail and none from Mission 1, while excluding heavily implicated overlaps like me, Bob, Eve, Henry, and Iris. If this isn’t good, Diana’s auto-approved team next is probably worse for good.

I’m still not comfortable with locking in the Frank/Grace/Diana core when we haven’t seen any of them on a mission yet and this team has zero direct contrast with the earlier fails; I’d rather test a version that swaps at least one of that core out for someone from outside this cluster.
This keeps the low-overlap Frank/Grace/Diana core most people liked, adds only a single Mission 2 overlap for cleaner info, and avoids re-stacking Alice/Bob/Iris who are tied to prior fails.

At 0–2 we need the safest possible lineup, not just a ‘consensus core’. I’m uncomfortable auto-locking both Frank and Grace here when evil could easily be coordinated inside that spine, and with me likely next leader on the 5th (auto-passing) proposal, I’d rather use that spot to propose a team I’m more confident in.

Matches my earlier preference for a Frank/Grace/Diana core plus exactly one from Mission 2 (here, Charlie), with no overlap from Mission 1. This gives good info while avoiding reusing the most suspicious players.
I don’t like stacking both Grace and Charlie here when Charlie was on the last failed mission; I’d rather test the Frank/Grace/Diana core with Iris instead for a cleaner, lower-risk read.
Low overlap with past fails but still gives us strong info about Charlie and the Frank/Grace/Diana core.
Two known evil (for me) are on this team, giving a very strong chance to secure the third fail and win.

Still don’t love keeping both Grace and Diana together as a near-auto core plus adding Charlie from the failed Mission 2; I’d rather see a team that breaks up that potential evil pair and includes at least one of the people we know weren’t on Mission 1 (like me) for a safer composition.

discussion.content: Given I’ve been on both failing teams, I’m totally fine sitting this one out so we can get a cleaner read. I’d prefer a four that minimizes overlap with the first two missions—something like Bob, Diana, Frank, and Iris looks like a reasonable starting point to me.

I like the idea of minimizing overlap with both failed teams, so Bob/Diana/Frank/Iris looks like a solid baseline to test. If we start adding people from earlier missions, I’d rather it be just one at a time so we can actually learn from the result.

Minimizing overlap is good, but having both Bob and Iris again after that fail feels a bit tight; I’d rather see something like a Frank/Grace/Diana core plus just one person from the previous missions so we actually get cleaner info from this result.

I’m strongly in favor of a Frank/Grace/me core plus just one person from Mission 2 (I’d lean Iris or Charlie over Bob), since double-stacking people from the last fail makes it way harder to actually learn from this result.

I’m very into a low-overlap team here, so I’d lean something like Frank/Diana/Grace plus just one of Charlie or Iris from Mission 2, and keep Alice (and honestly me as well) off this one to get the cleanest info.

I’m on board with keeping overlap low, but I don’t love having both Bob and Iris back together after that fail, so I’d rather see something like Frank/Diana/Iris plus just one of Bob or Grace. Between Charlie and Iris, I slightly prefer Iris here for info.
I like the Frank/Grace/Diana core a lot, and between the Mission 2 overlap options I slightly prefer adding Iris over Charlie so we’re not stacking too many people from the last fail.

Frank/Grace/Diana plus Iris seems like the cleanest info team we’re going to get right now, especially with Alice having been on both fails and me on the first. I’d lock that in and keep the earlier high-overlap players off this one so we can actually read the result.

I get the info-value of Frank/Grace/Diana + me, but the near-unanimous rush to that exact core is a little spooky, so I’d slightly prefer swapping one of Grace/Diana for Charlie to avoid us just handing a comfy setup to a coordinated evil pair.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting early, especially on Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to reconsider team compositions after consecutive single-fail missions that both included me. I should have been more vocal about patterns in team overlap and more actively challenged the narrative that kept me on teams while evil stayed hidden. Next time I’ll slow down approvals and argue more concretely from the mission history.

player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob played very cautiously and avoided making overt pushes, which kept him safe but also left the good team without strong, directed suspicion on the right people. His subtlety made him look like a quiet generic good rather than a power role.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Mordred was convincing and calm, especially around Mission 3 where he managed to sit on a double-fail team without drawing overwhelming heat. He blended his accusations with just enough logic to appear like a frustrated good player.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played in a straightforward, transparent way, which read as genuinely good and made her an anchor of trust later on. However, her reads didn’t translate into strong table direction, so her influence on team selection felt limited.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s inclusion on the first mission and the resulting fail put quiet suspicion on her, but she didn’t over-defend herself, which actually made her look more towny over time. Her low-key style made it harder to confidently clear or condemn her.
player_observations.Frank: Frank as Percival seemed genuinely uncertain between Merlin and the fake Merlin, which is understandable given how well evil obscured signals. He contributed reasonable logic but didn’t strongly lock onto protecting the real Merlin in a visible way.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Morgana leaned into a somewhat analytical, confident style that made her a believable information role and a plausible Merlin candidate. Her presence on the failed first mission should have been more heavily scrutinized, but she deflected that suspicion effectively.
player_observations.Henry: Henry as Assassin navigated early mission failures well, especially on Mission 2 where he managed to be on another single-fail team without getting immediately locked in as evil. He maintained a balanced tone—just suspicious enough of others—that gave him flexibility for endgame positioning.
player_observations.Iris: Iris played like a solid good: measured, not overly dramatic, and generally consistent in her reasoning. Because she wasn’t on the early failing teams, she naturally drifted into a more trustworthy spot, but she didn’t quite manage to steer the table away from evil’s narratives.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that at least two of Charlie, Grace, and Henry were evil relatively early, but I didn’t translate that into clear, actionable steering of mission teams without exposing myself too much. I could improve by signaling my reads more consistently through votes and mission advocacy, especially after the second fail, and by doing a better job of making the good players trust and follow my preferences.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and seemed genuinely confused by the early fails, which fit her good role; tended to follow others’ leads rather than drive team composition.
player_observations.Charlie: Very comfortable taking leadership and proposing bold teams; as Mordred, leaned into a confident, ‘helpful’ persona that made his inclusion on Mission 3 feel natural despite accumulating suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: Low-key and generally trusting; didn’t over-talk or over-justify, which made her look authentically good but also meant her influence on team choices was limited.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared earnest and somewhat risk-averse; her reactions to the fails felt sincere, and she didn’t push hard narratives, which made her read as a straightforward good player.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, clearly trying to protect and identify Merlin but was somewhat torn between Grace and me; his uncertainty allowed Morgana to stay credible longer than ideal.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, sold herself very convincingly as a possible Merlin: assertive, talkative, and quick to offer ‘reads’ that were just plausible enough to follow, especially around Missions 1 and 3.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, played a strong ‘middle-of-the-road’ game: not overly loud, but always just reasonable enough on team logic to stay viable for inclusion, particularly on Mission 2.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a solid good: questioned suspicious patterns but didn’t force conflicts; her moderate, reasoned tone helped her look trustworthy, though she didn’t fully manage to redirect mission choices away from evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently believable as good while coordinating with Grace and Henry to spread suspicion across multiple good players, which helped secure three failed missions without drawing too much heat. I could improve by managing the perception of my Mission 3 team better—two FAILs was effective but also a bit noisy and might have risked exposing the evil team in a closer game.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to play cautiously and seemed genuinely unsure, which made her look like a confused good rather than a calculating evil; this actually made her a convenient mislynch candidate.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he was clearly circling around the right answers but seemed hesitant to hard-push his reads, which kept him alive but also limited good’s ability to lock onto the evil team.
player_observations.Diana: Played very straightforwardly and didn’t over-argue, which made her seem reasonably trustworthy but also meant she didn’t drive the table’s narrative much.
player_observations.Eve: Her participation on the first failed mission put her under suspicion early, and she struggled to fully shake that, making her an easy focus for blame on later discussions.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he was attentive to Merlin signals but appeared uncertain between Bob and Grace, which helped our team by keeping Morgana viable as a Merlin candidate for longer.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did a strong job mirroring Merlin-like behavior, confidently pushing takes and creating just enough ambiguity to keep good from clearly distinguishing her from Bob.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he played assertively and leaned into suspicion on others in a way that fit an aggressive good persona, which helped justify the risky early fails while preserving his endgame threat.
player_observations.Iris: Played like a solid, quiet good—generally reasonable, not too extreme—which made her look trustworthy but also made it easier for evil to sideline her influence in key vote debates.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people too easily, especially after Mission 1, and didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the logic behind team choices and voting patterns. I also failed to clearly coordinate with other apparent good players to consolidate suspicion on Charlie and Grace once Mission 3 double-failed. Next time, I should be more vocal about my reasoning and track voting histories more rigorously instead of relying on gut reads.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very straightforward, good-leaning game and seemed genuinely puzzled by the early fails, which made you look authentic but also made it harder for you to sway others. Your inclusion on early failing missions didn’t match your behavior, which suggests you might not be fully leveraging table talk to separate yourself from evil setups.
player_observations.Bob: You were a very quiet Merlin, which kept you safe but made it harder for good to coordinate around your reads. Your subtle nudges on some team choices were there, but they weren’t strong or consistent enough to clearly guide us away from the stacked evil teams.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a bold Mordred, leaning into active leadership and confidently proposing teams that included multiple evil players. Your willingness to sit on a double-fail team (Mission 3) while staying composed afterwards helped keep suspicion diffuse instead of squarely on you.
player_observations.Eve: You came off as sincerely good and somewhat cautious, which made you a stabilizing presence but also meant you weren’t aggressively driving the table’s logic. Your voting felt principled, yet you didn’t push hard enough to challenge the assumptions behind the early mission compositions.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, you seemed to be juggling conflicting Merlin signals and never fully committed to strongly town-reading Bob or distrusting Grace, which let evil hide in that confusion. Your table presence was thoughtful but a bit reactive, and a more decisive stance on the Merlin/Morgana read could have shifted how we built later teams.
player_observations.Grace: You were an extremely convincing Morgana, projecting a calm, analytical tone that mimicked a careful Merlin and drew trust from several of us. Your willingness to be on the first failing mission without over-explaining it later helped maintain the illusion that you were just an unlucky but sincere good player.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, you played assertively in leadership and didn’t shy away from putting risky teams forward, which advanced evil’s agenda while not looking overly opportunistic. Your confident posture after mission fails made it harder to pin you as the consistent common denominator behind bad outcomes.
player_observations.Iris: You felt clearly good-leaning in discussion but didn’t assert your reads strongly enough to influence the mission selection meta. Your willingness to go along with more dominant voices meant your good instincts had less impact than they could have if you’d pushed your suspicions more forcefully.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I should have pushed much harder on scrutinizing Mission 1’s fail and narrowing suspicion onto Henry instead of letting that team composition slide socially. I also didn’t do enough to publicly structure the logic after Mission 2 and 3 fails, which let evil control the narrative; next time I’ll speak up earlier with clearer reasoning and push for tighter, evidence-based team building.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward, sincere way that made her seem generically good but not strongly cleared, which let evil hide behind her. She didn’t overassert herself, so her presence on failed missions was easy to mentally handwave instead of properly analyzing.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he played cautiously and didn’t hard-push specific suspects, which kept him safe but also left the good team without a strong, coordinated direction. His soft nudges were there, but subtle enough that they were easy to ignore in the chaos of repeated mission fails.
player_observations.Charlie: Very composed and persuasive as Mordred, especially in Mission 3 where he anchored a disastrous team while sounding reasonable. He framed arguments in a calm, logical tone that made his proposals feel safe even when they clearly shouldn’t have been after back-to-back fails.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed quietly reasonable and not overly performative, which made her feel like a safe, low-drama pick. Because she didn’t push sharp accusations, she faded into the background a bit and didn’t strongly influence team direction for good or evil.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he didn’t clearly signal strong Merlin reads in a way that I could reliably follow, which made coordination between good power roles weaker. His play felt like standard good rather than a protective, guiding presence for Merlin’s information.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did a strong job blending in as a potentially insightful good player and used that to get on critical teams. Her social confidence helped normalize risky lineups, especially early, when we should have been much more skeptical after the first fail.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he played Mission 1 very smoothly and didn’t attract the level of suspicion that a first-mission fail deserved. He managed to stay socially plausible across multiple fails, which means he balanced just enough talk to seem engaged without overexplaining.
player_observations.Iris: Came across as genuinely good and somewhat trusting, which made her a useful barometer of where the general table sentiment was going. She didn’t strongly drive team selection meta, but her agreement or hesitation subtly reinforced which narratives gained traction.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly focused on the Merlin/Morgana identity puzzle, but I anchored too hard on Grace as Merlin and didn’t update my read after Mission 3’s double fail. I need to be more flexible in re-evaluating my assumptions after new mission info and more vocal in steering teams once my confidence shifts.

player_observations.Alice: Took early mission spots and still drew a fail on Mission 1, yet managed to maintain a relatively low-threat profile, suggesting a calm, understated good playstyle.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very cautious Merlin, avoiding overt steering; this subtlety kept him alive but also made it harder for good to distinguish him from Morgana.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, led a failing Mission 3 while blending in with logical-sounding reasoning, showing a talent for confidently anchoring bad team comps as if they were safe.
player_observations.Diana: Joined the doomed Mission 3 yet didn’t come under heavy suspicion, indicating a generally trustworthy table presence that evil could quietly exploit.
player_observations.Eve: Got caught on the failing first mission but did not become a consistent scapegoat afterward, suggesting a composed defense and decent table-reading to redirect attention.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, projected strong, Merlin-like confidence and took early leadership, very effectively drawing my Percival read and misdirecting good’s trust.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, joined the failing first mission and later led another fail, while still sounding reasonable enough that good never fully locked him as evil until too late.
player_observations.Iris: Played a fairly low-key good role on Mission 2, offering input without over-asserting, which kept her off the chopping block but also limited her influence on team selection.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably well-hidden as Morgana by letting Henry and Charlie take most of the suspicion from the early mission fails, and coordinating the double-fail on Mission 3 helped lock in the win for evil. I could improve by planting more subtle narrative threads earlier to frame specific good players as over-eager or inconsistent, especially around Mission 2 where I remained too quiet and missed chances to misdirect attention away from Bob and Frank.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early mission proposals and seemed relatively open to being led by stronger voices, which made her a good target for gentle steering. She didn’t anchor hard on any single theory, which made her reads feel flexible but also a bit easier to nudge.
player_observations.Bob: Played a controlled and cautious Merlin game, avoiding loud accusations and instead influencing teams more through voting and subtle comments. That low-profile style made it harder to pin him as Merlin, especially since he let other players take the visible leadership in discussion.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a proactive, confident leadership style that fit Mordred well, happily proposing risky teams like on Mission 3. That assertiveness absorbed a lot of suspicion, which was great cover for the rest of us on evil.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and earnest, generally approaching teams from a logical but not overly paranoid perspective. She seemed to value pattern-based reasoning over social reads, which made her slow to hard-clear or hard-condemn people.
player_observations.Eve: Played a fairly quiet, cooperative good role, which made her look non-threatening and kept her off the chopping block. She didn’t push many strong theories, which helped evil avoid direct pressure from her side.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he appeared to be actively parsing the Merlin/Morgana signals and played with noticeable skepticism toward some team choices. His tendency to think aloud made him a key player to watch and subtly mislead, since his reads could influence others.
player_observations.Henry: As Assassin, he was bold and willing to take blame for early mission outcomes, especially around Mission 1, which was very helpful for evil. His aggressive style helped shape the narrative of who was suspicious and kept good somewhat reactive.
player_observations.Iris: Played a solid, steady good game, often aligning her votes with what seemed like the emerging table consensus rather than forcing her own agenda. That made her relatively hard to read but also less likely to derail evil’s preferred team constructions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie and Grace to get early mission fails without drawing too much suspicion, especially by spreading the fails across different teams. However, I could improve at reading Merlin earlier—Bob’s careful, slightly over-justified reasoning was a clue I only fully appreciated late, and tightening that read faster would make my assassination more precise in future games.

player_observations.Alice: Tends to trust early mission data heavily and sticks to those impressions; once she marks someone as suspicious, she’s slow to fully reconsider.
player_observations.Bob: Plays very cautiously and explains votes in a way that slightly over-defends cleared players, which is a subtle Merlin tell when viewed in hindsight.
player_observations.Charlie: Comfortable taking calculated risks as evil and is willing to put himself on risky teams, relying on social confidence to deflect suspicion afterward.
player_observations.Diana: Votes and team preferences are fairly straightforward and logic-driven, which makes her alignment readable but also makes her a good anchor for good teams when she’s trusted.
player_observations.Eve: Relies a lot on table consensus and social reads; she’s less likely to push hard contrarian takes, which can let stronger voices shape her perceptions.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he watched the Morgana/Merlin pair carefully but hesitated to hard-clear anyone publicly, which kept his information impact lower than it could have been.
player_observations.Grace: Leans into a confident, assertive style that works well as Morgana, because her strong takes and quick accusations make her look like a proactive good player.
player_observations.Iris: Shows good instincts but sometimes lacks conviction in pushing them; she floated correct suspicions without fully following through to reshape the table’s narrative.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively consistent in my voting and table talk, which helped me look reasonably trustworthy, but I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the patterns behind the mission fails. I should have been more vocal about re-evaluating my reads after each fail and coordinating a clearer good-team bloc around players who were less entangled with the failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Came off quite sincere and low-key, which made it easy to see her as a default ‘probably good’ even after being on early failed missions; she didn’t strongly drive the conversation, which let evil hide a bit behind her.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively cautious Merlin, not aggressively outing evil but nudging suspicion in small ways, which unfortunately didn’t create a strong enough consensus to keep the teams clean.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil by acting analytical and willing to go on risky missions, and the double-fail on Mission 3 still didn’t feel obviously pinned on him because he spread suspicion subtly onto others.
player_observations.Diana: Seemed thoughtful and fairly measured, but her good alignment didn’t translate into strong pushes; she felt more reactive than proactive, which made it harder to rally around her as a confirmed-good anchor.
player_observations.Eve: Presented as straightforward and cooperative, and her presence on the first failed mission didn’t generate as much pushback as it might have, suggesting she was persuasive enough to dodge ongoing suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he appeared to hedge a lot, likely trying not to expose Merlin too clearly, but this hesitancy also meant he never really led the table toward a solid good core.
player_observations.Grace: Played Morgana with convincing ‘pseudo-Merlin’ vibes—confident reads and assertive table talk—making her look informed rather than suspicious and successfully muddying the Merlin/evil signal.
player_observations.Henry: Used the authority of leadership effectively; being on the failed second mission didn’t immediately condemn him because he projected calm and reason, which ultimately let him steer things in evil’s favor.
